newsitem.title: USA: NY group says Cuomo tax cut aided poor, not Pataki.
newsitem.headline: NY group says Cuomo tax cut aided poor, not Pataki.

text.p: A non-profit research group took issue with New York State Gov George Pataki on Friday, saying that it was the tax cut enacted by former Gov Mario Cuomo that helped low-income families, not one implemented by Pataki.

The current governor on Thursday said that more than 450,000 New York residents were dropped from the tax rolls since 1994, when the last phase of the three-year personal income tax cut took effect on January 1.
The tax cuts total $3.9 billion and include more than $300 million in earned income tax credits for the working poor.

But the Fiscal Policy Institute, a Latham, N.Y.-based organization funded by advocacy groups and foundations, said about 84 percent of the tax reduction for these families was due to the $300 million Earned Income Tax Credit tax implemented by Cuomo.

The institute, in prepared remarks, said that Pataki's tax cut only raised to $22,358 the level below which families have a negative instead of a posive liablity. But the Cuomo Administration's tax cut ensured families whose annual incomes ranged from $14,150 to $21,750 owed no taxes, it added.
A spokesman for Pataki defended his Administration's tax reductions, and attacked the institute's neutrality.

"The governor's tax cut has helped working families and the middle class as well as low-income people as they move off welfare rolls into workforce. The fact that a liberal organization would take exception to something the governor has done is hardly news," said Mike McKeon.
The institute says that it is nonpartisan.
Pataki on January 8 is scheduled to release his state of the state annual address, which is expected to reveal some of the broad outlines of the 1998 fiscal budget due the following week.
The new budget is expected to include further tax reductions.

"I haven't seen the specifics, but clearly, we want to continue to lead the nation in tax cuts. We've done it for two years in a row, we will do it again in 1997, and I don't think that should be the end," Pataki told reporters in Albany on Thursday.
